displayed_text: Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: We got out of the car, I mean I couldn’t… Doctor: You felt it? Patient: Well I couldn’t step on it. I couldn’t walk up the step normally. I had to take the right leg up and take the right because if I try to go with this it’s just. Doctor: What’d you do in Alabama? Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I…

Family Member: It was very interesting. And we was laughing because- Doctor: What cities did you go to in South Africa? Did you visit any cities or-? Patient: We was all over the place. Family Member: Um hum. We was in Cape Town, Johannesburg, these little towns. Patient: Swaziland. Family Member: Swaziland. Patient: Zululand. Hazyview. Family Member: There, we had to cross the border. And so we had to go and show your passport, get stamped, or whatever, and go back across the border. Doctor: To Swaziland? Is that a-? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s like one of those little countries that’s inside of some? Patient: Um hum. Yeah.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No. Doctor: Man, it’s always your darn back. Family Member: Well, hip and leg. Doctor: Is it the hip and leg? Patient: Well, it’s, it like radiates from here down. Family Member: The pelvis down. Doctor: Uh, refresh my memory. Have we ever MRI’d that?

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step. Family Member: Right. Patient: So- Doctor: Yeah? Patient: That transfusion you’re talking about, you know, I read up on that way before I came to this hospital. Doctor: Um hum. Okay. Patient: It was a man that invented that transfusion and some other stuff they invented. What ever happened to him?

Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for. Doctor: Yeah I know. Healthcare Professional: He had a Buick Encore; that’s a nice car, too. Family Member: Yeah, that was a beautiful car. Doctor: Yeah, so now he’s. So she was sort of joking that if you get any girls’ phone calls, that’s the reason he’s getting them, not - Family Member: Oh my god! Patient: Yeah, “Mom, can I borrow your car?”

Doctor: In uh, Mo-Vember. Doctor: Mo-vember. So, that’s, uh, probably Australia. And, it’s, um, It’s a fundraiser - Patient: Ohhh! Doctor: For, uh, prostate cancer Patient: Oh! Doctor: Testes cancer, men’s health. Patient: I didn’t ever know. I didn’t realize, I didn’t realize this is my third year doing it, and I didn’t realize I was - Doctor: No shave, but I, I think that’s what that fundraiser is for. Patient: This is just County Sherriff’s Department. Doctor: No shave November. So, Movember, it is a big - they raise millions. Patient: No kidding. Doctor: They give, uh, grants and do a lot of support for, uh- Yeah, this is my eighth year. (softly) Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue that you run the risk is if it does show up and we'll catch it early or you're aware of it and it pops up in your lung. Patient: Yes, that’s not good. Doctor: That's something that can be associated with pain or sudden death. Patient: Right. That's right. My sister in law died of that. Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like.

Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. Doctor: No, my worry is that as we start chemo for the first few weeks of chemo until both of us figure out how you’re going to tolerate, how you’re going to do, maybe back off a little bit and take a break. Family Member: Back off on the - Doctor: And anyway, with the holidays maybe - Family Member: They did give him a set of exercises he can do – Doctor: Okay. Family Member: - at home. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Family Member: At home. Patient: Oh they’re stretching; they’re not - Doctor: Yeah, good, they’re not heavy-duty. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: No .No. No.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text:
Healthcare Professional 1: So did you make another appointment to see Dr. G____? Patient: Yeah uh uhhh… Doctor: Okay so they gave you enough? Patient: I think she said March – March, March something, March twenty-third or something. Doctor: Okay, alright. Patient: Twenty-second, twenty-third. Doctor: Let’s see what he finds. Okay so… Patient: I hope he don’t find nothing.
DOC Well good point. (Laughs) Doctor: This is your copy of the chemo consent. Okay? Alright so go over and we’ll go ahead with your treatment and you got all your scripts then. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: Everything else went electronically other that what you have in your hand. Okay?

Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah. Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. Doctor: Because that would be a really bad outcome overall. Patient: Yeah but it’s not like that so that’s… Doctor: Yeah, that’s a good thing. That’s why we’re having this back and forth even. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know I would tell you ditch this and just go get some other treatment. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So for now we gave you the pills for today. Patient: Right.

Family Member: No. I would still be doing the Germany thing, I just- Doctor: I mean I think we’ll do that uh you know really quickly if that’s what you wanted to do. So I can work on that this week. Patient: Yeah. I appreciate that. Doctor: To find out - I’ll also see what I can find out about this test I mentioned then. Patient: Oh for the marker? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll just give us some information about uh uh you know we’ve learned that folks who have that marker, the cancer tends to be way more aggressive in addition to being less sensitive a hormone treatment, there may also be a marker, a change in the cancer that’s made it more aggressive. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, at least on the preliminary data, it looks like patients that live that long, have that marker, but it’s the guess if you have that marker, we should be more aggressive about- Patient: Treatment? Doctor: Chemo. And probably be putzing around I don’t know hormone or something, maybe do something more like PSMA or something like that. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Or more aggressive immune therapy, those kind of things. Family Member: Can, can you draw blood today for that?

Patient: What’s the number? Doctor: Excellent. Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that again? I’m sorry. Family Member: Hum? Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that? Family Member: Yes. (Patient gives phone number.) Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Beautiful. Okay. Need any refills on anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So hang on and watch out for the uh yeah uh the diet and we’ll see you back in six weeks. Piece of cake. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Sure. Is that legit? Are you going to behave for six weeks?

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer. Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they-
